Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Development of novel silicon microchamber to investigate mechanical and electrical properties of cochlear structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary function of the mammalian cochlea is to provide the brain with information about the acoustic environment - specifically, it decodes with a high degree of precision information about the frequency and intensity of incoming sounds. As a result, how the cochlea is able to achieve such remarkable frequency selectivity and high sensitivity has been a hot topic in hearing research. In order to better study how the cochlea functions, a novel microfluidic device will be developed and fabricated under the expertise of Dr. Yong-Jin Yoon at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. The creation of a device that imitates several features of the cochlea will allow us to better identify the operating principles of the mammalian cochlea, and make contributions not only to the field of hearing research, but also the field of mechano-transduction in general.

According to the prevalent theory, the cochlea achieves frequency selectivity through mechanical resonance of a central partition that holds the sensory epithelium. However, experimental ground supporting this theory is weak, and existing measurements of the mechanical properties of the cochlear partition still do not provide clear evidence for this theory. For example, previous measurements of cochlear partition stiffness are measured using point force, rather than the more physiologically relevant form of fluid pressure. In an effort to overcome this problem, a microfluidic chamber that imitates the cochlear compartments will be developed. This microchamber will allow to place excised sections of the cochlear partition from an animal model in an environment that is physiologically, mechanically, and electrically similar to its in vivo state. The excised section of the cochlear partition is then stimulated with fluid pressure, and nanoscale measurements of the tissue displacement in all three dimensions are recorded. A previous design of the microchamber was fabricated using stereolithography, but calibration of electromechanical stimuli has proven to be difficult. To overcome the limitations of the current design, a new silicon-chip version of the microchamber will be designed and fabricated using standard microfabrication techniques. This technology will allow to add features such as an embedded pressure transducer for the calibration of fluid pressure applied to tissue specimens. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary research goal of the principal investigator is to study the mechanics of the cochlear partition to better understand how the cochlea achieves frequency tuning. The experimental techniques used in studying the mechanics of the cochlear partition have been very limited because the cochlea is encased in bone as well as its complex geometry (small scale, spiral shape). As a result, nearly all measurements of the mechanical properties of the cochlear partition and its structures (such as stiffness) have been completed using a compliant microprobe that applies a point force to the tissue, rather than the more physiologically relevant stimulation of fluid pressure. The goal of this research project was to develop a new experimental technique where excised sections of the cochlear partition are placed into a microfluidic chamber that recreates the natural tissue mechanical environment, and then stimulate it by calibrated fluid pressures at a wide range of acoustic frequencies.

We aimed to fabricate the novel microfluidic chamber using standard microfabrication techniques with silicon as a substrate. The layout and design of the microchambers were first assessed for potential issues or limitations by rapid prototyping using poly-methyl-methacrylate as a substrate, with laser-cutting to etch out the desired features. After finalizing the design, the fabrication process for the silicon version of the chamber was laid out, and the necessary materials and components were ordered. A second fabrication process was explored in parallel using stereolithography, which was eventually chosen due to its ease of manufacture.

During the research project, the principal investigator received education and training by researchers at the host laboratory at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. He gained skills to use CAD design software critical to his work as well as experience with microfabrication techniques such as laser-cutting, photolithography, and wet etching. The research allows for future collaboration between the principal investigator’s home lab at University of Rochester and the host lab in Singapore, with the potential to host one exchange student from Nanyang Technological University to participate in research at the University of Rochester.

While the funded work did not provide results that were immediately publishable, it was critical in providing the principal investigator the experimental technique and methodology necessary to his long-term research goals of studying cochlear biophysics. The stereolithography-fabricated design allowed the principal investigator to successfully measure the stiffness of the cochlear partition using fluid pressures, the results of which will be published in the near future. The principal investigator also disseminated research results in the form of two presentations, one at the National University of Singapore in Singapore, as well as at his home university (University of Rochester).
